The fallacy that is confusing you is this: You are thinking of gravity as being ‘caused’ by gravitons. It isn’t! It is caused by the presence in a region of space of matter, energy, momentum and pressure (ie, a non zero energy momentum tensor at least in some region of the region you are looking at). This produces a non zero gravitational field at every point in spacetime. If, after a while, the black hole stabilises, the contribution it makes to the gravitational field throughout space stabilises too. But… Say the black shreds another star for breakfast (cosmic shreddies? Kellogg’s is missing a trick!!), then the region around the black hole will have a changing energy momentum tensor, and it is HERE where the gravitons enter the scene: They carry the message to the rest of the Universe that Sagittarius A* has just eaten its breakfast and has fractionally increased its event horizon to accommodate the extra entropy it has gobbled up. The rest of the Universe is very interested in this information about Sagittarius A*’s breakfast and each point duly updates its gravitational field value as soon as it receives the good tidings, courtesy of a graviton messenger boy.  So, in summary, gravitons don’t cause gravity, the gravitational FIELD does that. What gravitons do is tell field values in other places how to change. And that is why, believe it or not, if you drop a brick, it falls on your toes.  Of course, this is not a mathematically precise way of putting it. It doesn’t tell you about virtual gravitons leaping around between the brick and the earth, not to mention your foot. But it serves to illustrate that the graviton does not have to escape the black hole to transmit gravity to its breakfast and suck it into its gaping maw. It is the changing energy momentum tensor in the space outside the black hole that dispatches the gravitons on their way across the cosmos. And when a black holes tries to eat another black hole, and viceversa, that we hairless apes get to measure the little critters and jump for joy at the invitation to visit Stockholm, all expenses paid.

to turn those singsong statements into useful math.  After a decade  of work, and buckets of differential geometry (needed to deal with  messed up coordinate systems like the surface of Earth, or worse, curved  spacetime) the “Einstein Field Equations” were eventually derived, and  presumably named after Einstein’s inspiration: the infamous Professor  Field.  This  is technically 16 equations (μ and ν are indices that take on 4 values  each), however there are tricks to get that down to a more sedate 6  equations.The left side of this horrible mess describes the shape of spacetime  and relates it to the right side, which describes the amount of matter  and energy (doesn’t particularly matter which) present.  This equation  is based on two principles: “matter and energy make gravity… somehow”  and “when you don’t feel a push or pull in any direction, then you’re  moving in a straight line”.  That push or pull is defined as what an  accelerometer would measure.  So satellites are not  accelerating because they’re always in free-fall, whereas you are  accelerating right now because if you hold an accelerometer it will read  9.8m/s2 (1 standard Earth gravity).  Isn’t that weird?  The  path of a freely falling object (even an orbiting object) is a straight  line through a non-flat spacetime.  Moving past the mind-bending weirdness; this equation, and all of the mathematical mechanisms of relativity, work perfectly for every prediction that we’ve been able to test.   So experimental investigation has given General Relativity a ringing  endorsement.  It’s not used/taught/believed merely because it’s pretty,  but because it works.Importantly, the curvature described isn’t merely dependent on the  presence of “stuff”, but on the curvature of the spacetime nearby.   Instead of being emitted from some distant source, gravity is a property  of the space you inhabit right now, right where you are.  This is the  important point that the “bowling ball on a sheet” demonstration is trying to get across.The  Einstein Field Equations describe the stretching of spacetime as being  caused both by the presence of matter and also by the curvature of  nearby spacetime.  Gravity doesn’t “reach out” any more than the metal  ball in the middle is.So here’s the point.  Gravity is just a question of the “shape” of  spacetime.  That’s affected by matter and energy, but it’s also affected  by the shape of spacetime nearby.  If you’re far away from a star (or  anything else really) the gravity you experience doesn’t come directly  that star, but from the patch of space you’re sitting in.  It turns out that if that star gets smaller and keeps the same mass, that the shape  of the space you’re in stays about the same (as long as you stay the  same distance away, the density of an object isn’t relevant to its  gravity).  Even if that object collapses into a black hole, the gravity  field around it stays about the same; the shape of the spacetime is  stable and perfectly happy to stay the way it is, even when the matter  that originally gave rise to it is doing goofy stuff like being a black  hole.This stuff is really difficult / nigh impossible to grok directly.  All we’ve really got are the experiments and observations, which led to a couple simple statements,  which led to some nasty math, which led to some surprising predictions  (including those concerning black holes), which so far have held up to  all of the observations of known black holes that we can do (which is  difficult because they’re dark, tiny, and the closest is around 8,000 light years away, which is not walking-distance).  That said: the math comes before understanding, and the math doesn’t come easy.Here’s the bad news.  In physics we’ve got lots of math, which is  nice, but no math should really be trusted to predict reality without  lots of tests and verification and experiment (ultimately that’s where  physics comes from in the first place).  Unfortunately no information  ever escapes from beyond the event horizon.  So while we’ve got lots of  tests that can check the nature of gravity outside of the horizon (the  gravity here on Earth behaves in the same way that gravity well above  the horizon behaves), we have no way even in theory to  investigate the interior of the event horizon.  The existence of  singularities, and what’s going on in those extreme scenarios in  general, may be a mystery forever.  Maybe.

Gravitons are massless particles, like photons. So they follow the same paths that photons do (the technical term is "null geodesic"). Since photons cannot escape the event horizon of a black hole, gravitons can't either. However, gravitons don't actually need to escape a black hole in order for you to detect its gravity. The gravity you feel at a particular point in spacetime is determined by the local curvature of spacetime at that point. Therefore, you don't need to know what's going on inside the black hole in order to feel the curvature of spacetime outside it. (Important remark: The picture of gravitons as the "mediators" of gravity, like photons are the mediators of the electromagnetic interaction, is actually incorrect. Unlike the electromagnetic interaction, gravity is fundamentally nonlinear. But gravitons are the quanta of linearized gravity, which means they are only suitable for describing very weak gravitational fields, such as gravitational waves. Black holes are, obviously, the complete opposite of weak and therefore a description of them using gravitons is inadequate. We don't know what the quantum description of nonlinear gravity is, and that is in fact one of the things a full theory of quantum gravity must be able to explain.)

Gravity at a black hole event horizon doesn't have to be strong. The larger and larger the black hole is, the weaker than gravity is at the event horizon. The event horizon is a global property of space-time of having trapped light cones such that light cannot escape to infinity. We should not need quantum gravity to calculate things at the event horizon of a very large black hole. Virtual gravitons, like virtual photons, are purely a calculational device of pertubative quantum field theory. Virtual gravitons aren't real, so it makes no sense to talk about them escaping from the event horizon. See Frank Heile's answer to Quantum Field Theory: The Coulomb force between electrical charges is caused by exchange of photons. What is really going on, how is the transfer of these virtual particles responsible for such important phenomena we experience in our daily lives? . On others hand, Hawking radiation should produce real photons and genuine gravitons which do escape to infinity. These genuine particles originate from simply outside of the event horizon.

You need to distinguish between real and virtual particles. While it is true that no real graviton can escape an event horizon (hence, whatever happens inside the event horizon cannot produce gravitational radiation), virtual gravitons (responsible for the gravitational interaction between two bodies) are not constrained this way. (The same way, a Reissner-Nordström black hole can have a static electric charge.) Another important point is that insofar as the outside world is concerned, the event horizon remains forever in the future. I.e., you never see the event horizon form; all you see is infalling matter, infinitely redshifted, but never really crossing the horizon, ever. So if you are an outside observer, all the mass of the black hole is still sitting just outside the event horizon, perfectly capable of interacting with everything else without escaping from a horizon that has not even formed yet.

There is no simple answer to this question because we don't have a quantum theory of gravity. So all we can say is that, if we were to apply the current methods of quantum field theory to gravity, disregarding the fact that the resulting theory breaks down at higher orders of perturbation theory, this is how we would approach it: We would split the gravitational field into two parts: the classical background, which is the solution to Einstein's equations, and the quantum field, which is the perturbation around that background field. It's this quantum perturbation that we would interpret as gravitons.  When you split the field in this way, the effective Lagrangian that describes quantum field will contain terms, which can be interpreted as (virtual) graviton(s) interacting with the vacuum: being created from nothing or disappearing into nothingness (as long as the conservation laws permit it).  So if you wanted to describe the behavior of an elementary particle near a black hole; to the first approximation, it would just interact with the classical background field, which is the Schwarzschild solution of Einstein equations. Then you would add to it quantum corrections in the form of exchanging virtual gravitons with the vacuum. And here's the big problem: quantum corrections in gravity turn out to be infinite, and we have no way of absorbing them into the free parameters of the theory. We say that such theory is not renormalizable.  Except for the problem of renormalizability, all other elements of this picture are known from other quantum theories. The background field formalism is used to calculate quantum corrections in the presence of classical electric or magnetic fields (where virtual photons may pop out or disappear into vacuum). Virtual Higgs particles interact with the Higgs condensate. You may even think of the background field as some kind of graviton condensate, in analogy to Higgs vacuum, if that helps.  Obviously this picture is incomplete (one could say it's full of holes) because, as I said, there is no quantum theory of gravity; and the perturbation theory, which we use to calculate quantum effects, only works in the weak field regime.

The simple answer is we’re not really sure gravitons exist. Gravity is not a force like electromagetism - rather, gravity is our simplified understanding of the curvature of spacetime. Thus it doesn’t need particles to interact. As Wheeler nicely summed up General Relativity, “Spacetime tells matter how to move; matter tells spacetime how to curve”. Also, it begs the question of the speed of light. There is no such thing per se as the speed of light. c refers to causality. Light, by its own frame of reference, is instantaneous and timeless, it is only by the perspective of a massive stationary object (i.e., us) that it appears to move. So while electromagnetic particles and photons can’t escape a black hole, gravity itself has nothing to escape.

We don’t need to postulate gravitons. The gravitational field will do just fine. The thing about event horizons is that they are as extreme as you can get. The river of space-time flows into black holes at light speed. Anything going at light speed essentially traverses all future time and space instantly from its frame of reference, but from our frame of reference nothing will get past the event horizon due to gravitational time dilation. Matter will approach it and in the very last microseconds slow down and fade from view. So from our frame of reference we can consider the event horizon itself (strictly speaking , just this side of it), to contain the gravitational field and all the mass/energy of the black hole. From an external frame of reference there is simply never a point-like singularity at the centre of the black hole. So the gravitational field and the mass/energy and the magnetic charge are still in the universe. This resolves the contradiction.

Nothing can escape from the event horizon of a black hole.  Gravitational waves from black hole binaries are formed outside the event horizons of the black holes, though close to them.  Roughly you can think of it as follows.  Any massive body curves the space-time around it, this is what creates the force of gravity  in general relativity.  The massive black holes distort space-time significantly, especially near the event horizons.  As they orbit each other this curvature of space-time oscillates and produces ripples in space-time which propagate outward.  These are gravitational waves.

Hawking now proposes that the event horizons are “apparent horizons” which suck in matter and energy — but only temporarily, before eventually releasing them again. To be clear, Hawking isn’t proposing that black holes don’t exist — just that black holes, as we’ve understood them for the last 40 years or so, don’t exist. The current understanding is that black holes are surrounded by an event horizon — a boundary in spacetime which only allow matter and energy to pass through one way, towards the black hole. The problem with this theory is that it’s based on general relativity and in recent years, as our understanding of quantum theory has improved, numerous conflicts have arisen. Basically, quantum mechanics has a big issue with the idea that event horizons completely and utterly destroy information — a big no-no in the world of quantum. Hawking’s new proposal tries to ameliorate this. Thus, for now, it is hard to say whether gravitons can escape the black hole or not.

Once a black hole is formed, gravitational waves are not radiated from the event horizon.  That is essentially the definition of the event horizon.  Gravitational radiation that comes from the later stages of collapse is emitted in the region external to the black hole. Particles and fields have entirely different behavior. Gravitons cannot escape from a black hole, according to the physics that says photons cannot escape, and for the same reason. But fields do not escape from black holes, and do not need to. An electric field, or a magnetic field, or a gravitational field, or the Higgs field, or dark energy, exist throughout spacetime, but at different strengths and polarizations at each point. The fields produced by the matter that falls in and creates a black hole were already there, inside and outside the Schwarzschild radius, when the black hole formed, and had no reason to disappear. Similarly, the effects of spin extend into the ergosphere and beyond. Changes in the fields propagate at the speed of light, but those changes are not particles, and are not subject to gravity.
